feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates daily pay by dividing the employee's total salary (basic plus allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month, accounting for public holidays. The feature automatically generates pay deductions that are reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests. It supports both calendar day-based and working day-based leave policies, ensuring accurate salary reductions based on organizational leave policies. The daily wage calculator ensures consistent and compliant payroll processing for unpaid leave scenarios.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the daily pay formula (Salary / Actual Working Days), describes the difference between calendar day and working day leave policies, and explains how public holidays are subtracted from working days to calculate actual working days. The article confirms that automatic pay deductions are created upon approval of unpaid leave requests and reflected on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature as a flexible solution replacing previous limited wage calculation methods. Explains three calculation base options (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection, and the feature's impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Defines distinctions between calculation bases and notes that UAE and KSA companies typically use 30 custom days to comply with labor law.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how Super admins can update salary proration in the Daily Wage Calculator by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Describes the navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), the impact on active payroll amounts, and the required workflow for rejecting and resaving prorated transactions when payroll month is open.

job_to_be_done.statement: Calculate and deduct daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave by determining the appropriate salary reduction based on the number of working or calendar days in the month, accounting for public holidays.

To adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days)

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a pay deduction needs to be calculated and applied to an employee's salary.
steps: Receive and approve the unpaid leave request
Determine the leave policy type (calendar days or working days) applicable to the employee
Identify the total number of days in the leave policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the month
Subtract public holidays from the total working days to arrive at actual working days
Divide the employee's total salary (basic + allowance) by the actual working days
The result is the daily pay rate used to calculate the deduction for unpaid leave days
The system automatically creates a pay deduction record and reflects it on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for payroll processing.
steps: Navigate to Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
System applies selected configuration to salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to adjust how employee salaries are prorated based on actual days worked
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis (custom days, calendar days, or working days)
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject existing transactions and resave the proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month. ; The number of days used in calculation can be either calendar days (if following calendar days leave policy, e.g., 30 days) or working days (if following working days leave policy, e.g., 22 working days). ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days to arrive at actual working days for daily pay calculation. ; Daily pay deduction is automatically created and applied only upon approval of the unpaid leave request.

Calendar days calculation base counts all days in a given month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February). ; Working days calculation base excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Custom days calculation base allows payroll table managers to set a fixed number of days according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to comply with local labor law. ; Only Superadmin, Payroll table managers, or transaction processors can select and modify the calculation base.

Changes to salary proration settings will have an effect on all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new proration changes

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays occur during the month, they must be subtracted from the working days total. For example, if 2 days are public holidays and the leave policy is 22 working days, daily pay is calculated on 20 days, not 22 days. ; The calculation differs based on leave policy: calendar day-based policies use fixed day counts (e.g., 30 days) while working day-based policies use working days (e.g., 22 days), both subject to public holiday deductions.

Calculation results vary by month when using calendar days due to different month lengths; February has 28 days while January has 31 days, which directly impacts daily wage rates. ; Different calculation methods (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) can produce significantly different final wage calculations for the same employee, affecting salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions before saving new salary proration settings to prevent conflicts

Daily Wage Calculator interacts with Salary proration, Leave encashment, and Unpaid leave deduction features; configuration changes directly impact calculations in all three areas. ; When working days calculation base is selected, the feature depends on the company's public holiday calendar to accurately exclude non-working days.
Daily Wage Calculator interacts with the Payroll system and affects active payroll table transactions, including first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations
